title: 2011–12 Welsh Premier League
text:
The 2011–12 Welsh Premier League season was the 20th season of the <a href="Welsh%20Premier%20League">Welsh Premier League</a>, the highest <a href="association%20football">football</a> league of <a href="Wales">Wales</a> since its establishment in 1992. <a href="Bangor%20City%20F.C.">Bangor City</a> were the defending champions, but lost their title to <a href="The%20New%20Saints%20F.C.">The New Saints</a> in a meeting on the final game of the season.
Teams.
<a href="Haverfordwest%20County%20F.C.">Haverfordwest County</a> were relegated to the 2011–12 <a href="Welsh%20Football%20League%20Division%20One">Football League Division One</a> at the end of the <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20Welsh%20Premier%20League">2010–11 season</a> after finishing at the bottom of the table. The club thus ended a fourteen-year tenure in the league. They were replaced by <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20Welsh%20Football%20League%20Division%20One">2010–11 Football League</a> runners-up <a href="Afan%20Lido%20F.C.">Afan Lido</a>, who returned to the Premier League after six seasons.
Originally, <a href="Bala%20Town%20F.C.">Bala Town</a> as 11th-placed team were going to be relegated as well; however, they were eventually spared as <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20Cymru%20Alliance">2010–11 Cymru Alliance</a> champions <a href="Connah%27s%20Quay%20Nomads%20F.C.">Connah's Quay Nomads</a> were denied a Premier League licence.
League table.
<onlyinclude></onlyinclude>
Results.
Teams played each other twice on a home and away basis, before the league was split into two groups at the end of round 22 – the top six and the bottom six.
Clubs in these groups played each other twice again bringing the total fixture count to 32.
Matches 23–32.
Top six
Bottom six
UEFA Europa League play-offs.
Teams who finished in positions fourth through eighth at the end of the season participated in a play-off to determine the second participant for the <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20UEFA%20Europa%20League">2012–13 UEFA Europa League</a>. As Neath failed to win their appeal against an FAW Domestic licence, Aberystwyth Town took their place (See <a href="2011%E2%80%9312%20Welsh%20Premier%20League%23Relegation%20issues">Relegation Section</a>)
